definition: A word that names a person, place, thing, or idea. Nouns can function as subjects, objects, or complements in sentences.
A word that expresses an action, occurrence, or state of being. Verbs tell us what the subject is doing or what is happening.
A word that takes the place of a noun or noun phrase. Pronouns help avoid repetition and make writing more fluid.
A word that modifies or describes a noun or pronoun. Adjectives provide more information about the person, place, thing, or idea.
A word that modifies a verb, adjective, or another adverb. Adverbs tell how, when, where, or to what extent something happens.
A word that shows the relationship between a noun or pronoun and other words in a sentence. Prepositions often indicate location, time, or direction.
A word that connects words, phrases, or clauses. Conjunctions help join ideas and show relationships between them.
The part of a sentence that performs the action or is being described. The subject is usually a noun or pronoun.
The part of a sentence that contains the verb and tells something about the subject. The predicate includes the verb and all its modifiers.
A noun or pronoun that receives the action of a verb or is affected by it. Objects can be direct or indirect.
A group of words that contains a subject and a verb. Clauses can be independent (complete sentences) or dependent (incomplete thoughts).
A group of words that work together but do not contain both a subject and a verb. Phrases function as single parts of speech.
The noun or noun phrase that a pronoun refers to or replaces. The antecedent usually comes before the pronoun.
The grammatical relationship between words that ensures they match in number, person, and gender.
The form of a verb that indicates when an action takes place - past, present, or future.
The form of a verb that indicates whether the subject performs the action (active voice) or receives the action (passive voice).
examples: The mouse was chased by the cat (passive)

definition: The form of a verb that indicates the speaker's attitude toward the action - indicative (fact), imperative (command), or subjunctive (wish/hypothesis).
A word, phrase, or clause that provides additional information about another word or group of words.
A word or group of words that completes the meaning of a subject, verb, or object.
An incomplete sentence that is missing either a subject, a verb, or a complete thought.
A sentence that contains two or more independent clauses that are not properly joined or separated.
examples: I went to the store I bought milk
She loves pizza he prefers pasta
